OO/Java is like that, when done well: a lot of small classes, a lot of inte=
rfaces and short methods with a lot of delegation. Some "OO" programmers an=
d many Java programmers don't get that that's a sign of *good* design. (It'=
s not a requirement of good design; it's a sign.)

Take care.

>So said Kat=
ie Gerg on 4/16/2003 --------------------
>I'll have to take a look at the =
TestRunner again.  I looked at the textui
>classes, ResultPrinter and TestR=
unner.  ResultPrinter implements
>TestListener, The TestRunner class extend=
s BaseTestRunner, which in turn
>implements TestListener - my head then exp=
loded - just kidding.    At any
>rate, I just by passed the runner and had =
the listener keep track of all
>the
>results, names, error/failure descript=
ions and detailed test case
>description in an object.
>
>I know this is a =
hack so I intend to go back and look at it later.

>  It sounds like all you needed=
 was to register a TestListener so that, for
>each test, you could collect =
its name. What you do with those names
>afterward is totally up to the indi=
vidual.
>
>  Writing the TestListener is nothing. Attaching the TestListene=
r to the
>TestRunner may take some work. I've never actually done it. I wou=
ld have to
>look at the code.
>
>  I suppose you could have written your ow=
n TestRunner that instantiates
>the
>text runner, adds the listener, asks t=
he text runner to run the tests, then
>processes the results from your list=
ener. Is this what you did? If not,
>then
>what did you do?
>
>  Thanks.

d to post it because I'm really serious when I say I

e to get a suite of automated tests done by the end of this

did it without completely understanding junit but I knew what I

e

es so I know what test cases I've run against
>a
>  >build (hey I'm a qa pe=
rson, I have to know what's in there not only what
>  >failed - esp. from a=
 test coverage perspective).  I also wanted it in a

 easily view, so I store the test results in a vector
>  >that I dump out i=
n an html format at the end (the location is hardcoded
>for

ll eventually come from a property file).

 same issue you had with the listener so I made

ct that the testcase class initializes and the

>  >grabs it from =
it.

ay of
